Combat Mode

Systems and mechanics for tactical battles and skirmishes

When initiative is rolled and characters are fighting for their lives, you're in Combat Mode. This highly structured mode uses turns, rounds, and precise movement to resolve conflicts.

Core Systems for Combat

Combat

The primary system for this mode:

  • Initiative: Determining turn order (DEX checks)
  • Rounds & Turns: Each round = 6 seconds, everyone gets one turn
  • Movement: Moving up to your Speed, difficult terrain
  • Attack Rolls: Melee, ranged, and spell attacks
  • Damage: Rolling damage dice and applying it to targets
  • Cover: Half cover (+2 AC/DEX), three-quarters cover (+5 AC/DEX)

Combat Actions

What you can do on your turn:

  • Attack: Make weapon or unarmed strike
  • Dash: Extra movement equal to your Speed
  • Disengage: Avoid opportunity attacks
  • Dodge: Impose disadvantage on attacks against you
  • Help: Give an ally advantage
  • Hide: Make a Stealth check
  • Ready: Prepare an action for a trigger

Damage & Healing

Managing hit points:

  • Damage Types: 13 types (slashing, fire, necrotic, etc.)
  • Resistance/Vulnerability/Immunity: Modifying damage taken
  • Critical Hits: Natural 20 = double damage dice
  • Healing: Spells, potions, Hit Dice during Short Rest
  • Death Saves: Three failures = death, three successes = stabilized

Combat Conditions

Common status effects:

  • Blinded, Deafened, Frightened: Sensory impairments
  • Grappled, Restrained, Paralyzed: Movement restrictions
  • Prone: Disadvantage on attacks, advantage for melee attackers
  • Stunned, Unconscious: Loss of actions

Transitioning Out of Combat Mode

Combat mode typically transitions to:

  • Exploration Mode: When combat ends and players investigate the area
  • Interaction Mode: When taking prisoners or negotiating surrender
  • Downtime Mode: When taking a Short Rest to heal and recover
